data.name: heading
data.body: Potential Energy in an External Electric Field

data.name: bold
data.body: 1) Potential Energy of a single charge

data.name: paragraph
data.body: In previous sections, the source of the electric field was specified â€“ the charges and their locations - and the potential energy of the system of those charges was determined. In this section, we ask a related but distinct question. What is the potential energy of a charge \(q\) in a given field? But here we address this question again to clarify in what way it is different from the earlier discussions.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The main difference is that we are now concerned with the potential energy of a charge (or charges) in an external field. The external field \(E\) is not produced by the given charge(s) whose potential energy we wish to calculate. \(E\) is produced by sources external to the given charge(s).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The external sources may be known, but often they are unknown or unspecified; what is specified is the electric field \(E\) or the electrostatic potential \(V\) due to the external sources. We assume that the charge \(q\) does not significantly affect the sources producing the external field.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: This is true if \(q\) is very small, or the external sources are held fixed by other unspecified forces. Even if \(q\) is finite, its influence on the external sources may still be ignored in the situation when very strong sources far away at infinity produce a finite field \(E\) in the region of interest. Note again that we are interested in determining the potential energy of a given charge \(q\) (and later, a system of charges) in the external field; we are not interested in the potential energy of the sources producing the external electric field.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The external electric field \(E\) and the corresponding external potential \(V\) may vary from point to point. By definition, \(V\) at a point \(P\) is the work done in bringing a unit positive charge from infinity to the point \(P\).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Thus, work done in bringing a charge \(q\) from infinity to the point \(P\) in the external field is \(qV\). This work is stored in the form of potential energy of \(q\). If the point \(P\) has position vector \(r\) relative to some origin, we can write:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \text{Potential energy of } q \text{ at } \mathbf{r} \text{ in an external field} = qV(\mathbf{r}) \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: where \(V(\mathbf{r})\) is the external potential at the point \(\mathbf{r}\). Thus, if an electron with charge \(q = e = 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{C}\) is accelerated by a potential difference of \(V = 1 \, \text{volt}\), it would gain energy of \(qV = 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J}\). This unit of energy is defined as \(1 \, \text{electron volt}\) or \(1 \, \text{eV}\), i.e., \(1 \, \text{eV} = 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \, \text{J}\). The units based on \(eV\) are most commonly used in atomic, nuclear, and particle physics, \(1 \, \text{keV} = 10^3 \, \text{eV} = 1.6 \times 10^{-16} \, \text{J}\), \(1 \, \text{MeV} = 10^6 \, \text{eV} = 1.6 \times 10^{-13} \, \text{J}\), \(1 \, \text{GeV} = 10^9 \, \text{eV} = 1.6 \times 10^{-10} \, \text{J}\), and \(1 \, \text{TeV} = 10^{12} \, \text{eV} = 1.6 \times 10^{-7} \, \text{J}\).

data.name: bold
data.body: 2) Potential energy of a system of two charges in an external electric field

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Next, we ask: what is the potential energy of a system of two charges \(q_1\) and \(q_2\) located at \(\mathbf{r}_1\) and \(\mathbf{r}_2\), respectively, in an external field?

data.name: paragraph
data.body: First, we calculate the work done in bringing the charge \(q_1\) from infinity to \(\mathbf{r}_1\). Work done in this step is \(q_1 V(\mathbf{r}_1)\). Next, we consider the work done in bringing \(q_2\) to \(\mathbf{r}_2\). In this step, work is done not only against the external field \(E\) but also against the field due to \(q_1\).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Work done on \(q_2\) against the external field \(= q_2 V (\mathbf{r}_2)\)

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Work done on \(q_2\) against the field due to \(q_1\) \(= \frac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r_{12}}\), where \(r_{12}\) is the distance between \(q_1\) and \(q_2\). By the superposition principle for fields, we add up the work done on \(q_2\) against the two fields (E and that due to \(q_1\)):

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \text{Work done in bringing } q_2 \text{ to } \mathbf{r}_2 = q_2 V (\mathbf{r}_2) + \frac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r_{12}} \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Thus, Potential energy of the system \(= \text{the total work done in assembling the configuration} \)

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ = q_1 V(\mathbf{r}_1) + q_2 V (\mathbf{r}_2) + \frac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r_{12}} \]

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ = q_1 V(\mathbf{r}_1) + q_2 V (\mathbf{r}_2) + \frac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r_{12}} \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: 3) Potential energy of a dipole in an external field

data.name: image
data.body: /assets/electrostatic-potential-and-capacitance/image2.png

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Consider a dipole with charges $q_1 = +q$ and $q_2 = -q$ placed in a uniform electric field $\mathbf{E}$, as shown in the figure. As seen in the last chapter, in a uniform electric field, the dipole experiences no net force but experiences a torque given by

data.name: expression
data.body: $\boldsymbol{\tau} = \mathbf{p} \times \mathbf{E}$

data.name: paragraph
data.body: which will tend to rotate it (unless $\mathbf{p}$ is parallel or antiparallel to $\mathbf{E}$). Suppose an external torque $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{\text{ext}}$ is applied in such a manner that it just neutralizes this torque and rotates it in the plane of paper from angle $\theta_0$ to angle $\theta_1$ at an infinitesimal angular speed and without angular acceleration. The amount of work done by the external torque will be given by

data.name: expression
data.body: \[W = \int_{\theta_0}^{\theta_1} \tau_{\text{ext}} \, d\theta = \int_{\theta_0}^{\theta_1} \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{E} \sin \theta \, d\theta = pE \left( \cos \theta_0 - \cos \theta_1 \right).\]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: This work is stored as the potential energy of the system. We can then associate potential energy $U(\theta)$ with an inclination of the dipole. Similar to other potential energies, there is a freedom in choosing the angle where the potential energy $U$ is taken to be zero. A natural choice is to take $\theta = 0$ (an explanation for it is provided towards the end of the discussion).

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ U(\theta) = pE \left( \cos \frac{\pi}{2} - \cos \theta \right) = pE \cos \theta = -\mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{E} \]

data.name: expression
data.body: $U'(\theta) = {q} \left[ V(\mathbf{r}_1) - V(\mathbf{r}_2) \right] -{\frac{q ^ 2}{4\epsilon_0\pi \times 2a} }.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Here, $\mathbf{r}_1$ and $\mathbf{r}_2$ denote the position vectors of $+q$ and $-q$. Now, the potential difference between positions $\mathbf{r}_1$ and $\mathbf{r}_2$ equals the work done in bringing a unit positive charge against the field from $\mathbf{r}_2$ to $\mathbf{r}_1$. The displacement parallel to the force is $2a \cos\theta$. Thus, $[V(\mathbf{r}_1) - V (\mathbf{r}_2)] = -E \times 2a \cos\theta$. We thus obtain,

data.name: expression
data.body: \[U'(\theta) = {-pE \cos\theta}-{\frac{q ^ 2}{4\epsilon_0\pi \times 2a} } = {-p.E}- {\frac{q ^ 2}{4\epsilon_0\pi \times 2a} }.\]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: We note that $U(\theta)$ differs from $U(\theta')$ by a quantity which is just a constant for a given dipole.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: We can now understand why we took $\theta = 0$. In this case, the work done against the external field $E$ in bringing $+q$ and $-q$ are equal and opposite and cancel out, i.e.,

data.name: expression
data.body: $q [V (\mathbf{r}_1) - V (\mathbf{r}_2)] = 0$
